name: Board Financial Reporting
description: Prepare quarterly or monthly financial reports for the Board of Directors. Includes performance summary, variance analysis, forward outlook, key risks, and strategic financial updates. Must be executive-ready and anticipate Board questions.

currentProcess.description: Gather financial data and finalize close
Build financial summary tables and charts
painPoints: Balance sheet, P&L, and cash flow alignment
Prioritizing which risks matter to Board

currentProcess.description: Create executive summary and key takeaways
Review with CFO and incorporate feedback
painPoints: CFO has different perspective on messaging

currentProcess.description: Prepare Q&A anticipation and backup slides
painPoints: Having data ready for deep dives

aiProcess.description: Structure data and create initial tables
aiProcess.expectedOutput: Formatted financial tables ready for presentation
tips: Use consistent formats from prior periods
Include prior period and budget columns

aiProcess.expectedOutput: Board-ready variance commentary for each major line
tips: Ask for 'CFO tone' - confident, clear, balanced

aiProcess.toolRationale: Claude can articulate uncertainty and outlook clearly
aiProcess.expectedOutput: Forward-looking section with appropriate confidence framing

aiProcess.toolRationale: Claude can prioritize and articulate risks clearly
tips: Include both financial and operational risks
Lead with the headline - overall health of business

aiProcess.toolRationale: Human review critical; AI helps with quick rewrites
Claude can anticipate sophisticated Board questions
aiProcess.expectedOutput: Top 10 likely questions with suggested answers
tips: Think about what each Board member typically asks
Include questions on the concerning items

whyItMatters: Board reporting is the highest-stakes financial communication. It shapes Board confidence in management, influences strategic decisions, and can impact funding, compensation, and company direction. Getting it right builds trust; getting it wrong erodes credibility.
commonMistakes: Too much detail - Boards want highlights, not data dumps
Burying bad news - better to lead with it and show you're on top of it
No forward outlook - Boards care more about future than past
Generic risks - be specific about YOUR company's risks
Not preparing for Q&A - anticipate and prepare for tough questions
tips: Create a 'Board member profile' - what does each typically ask about?
Use AI to role-play as a skeptical Board member
Draft the executive summary FIRST - it clarifies your key messages
Keep a 'Board Q&A library' that grows over time
sources: NACD (National Association of Corporate Directors) - Board reporting best practices
